body_html:
TensorFlow pip package depends on protobuf pip package version 3.1.0 according to the installation guide. In the common problems section.

Protobuf's pip package downloaded from PyPI (when running pip install protobuf) is a Python only library, that has Python implementations of proto serialization/deserialization which can be 10x-50x slower than the C++ implementation.

So essentially, the protobuf that comes with PyPI is slow and a c++ based one is much faster.

Yeah, python -c "from google.cloud import logging as gclogging;" succeeds if I don't install Protobuf with either the following command line

$ sudo pip install /tmp/tensorflow_pkg/tensorflow-0.11.0rc0-py2-none-any.whl
# OR
pip install --upgrade https://storage.googleapis.com/tensorflow/linux/cpu/protobuf-3.0.0-cp27-none-linux_x86_64.whl
# OR
pip install dist/protobuf-3.1.0-cp27-cp27mu-linux_x86_64.whl

Lastly, using pip install google-cloud doesn't work. In fact, I had to install from source since I was experiencing other problems with the google-cloud.

Also, @asimshankar, what exactly does the config option when running $ ./configure

Do you wish to build TensorFlow with Google Cloud Platform support? [y/N] N

Do?

TensorFlow pip package depends on protobuf pip package version 3.1.0 according to the installation guide. In the common problems section.

Protobuf's pip package downloaded from PyPI (when running pip install protobuf) is a Python only library, that has Python implementations of proto serialization/deserialization which can be 10x-50x slower than the C++ implementation.

So essentially, the protobuf that comes with PyPI is slow and a c++ based one is much faster.
Yeah, python -c "from google.cloud import logging as gclogging;" succeeds if I don't install Protobuf with either the following command line
$ sudo pip install /tmp/tensorflow_pkg/tensorflow-0.11.0rc0-py2-none-any.whl
# OR
pip install --upgrade https://storage.googleapis.com/tensorflow/linux/cpu/protobuf-3.0.0-cp27-none-linux_x86_64.whl
# OR
pip install dist/protobuf-3.1.0-cp27-cp27mu-linux_x86_64.whl

Lastly, using pip install google-cloud doesn't work. In fact, I had to install from source since I was experiencing other problems with the google-cloud.

Do?
body:
TensorFlow pip package depends on protobuf pip package version 3.1.0 according to the [installation guide](https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/blob/master/tensorflow/g3doc/get_started/os_setup.md#installing-from-sources). In the **common problems** section.

> Protobuf's pip package downloaded from PyPI (when running pip install protobuf) is a Python only library, that has Python implementations of proto serialization/deserialization which can be 10x-50x slower than the C++ implementation. 

So essentially, the protobuf that comes with PyPI is slow and a c++ based one is much faster.

Yeah, `python -c "from google.cloud import logging as gclogging;"` succeeds if I don't install Protobuf with either the following command line

```
$ sudo pip install /tmp/tensorflow_pkg/tensorflow-0.11.0rc0-py2-none-any.whl
# OR
pip install --upgrade https://storage.googleapis.com/tensorflow/linux/cpu/protobuf-3.0.0-cp27-none-linux_x86_64.whl
# OR
pip install dist/protobuf-3.1.0-cp27-cp27mu-linux_x86_64.whl
```

Lastly, using `pip install google-cloud` doesn't work. In fact, I had to install from source since I was experiencing other problems with the google-cloud.

Also, @asimshankar, what exactly does the config option when running `$ ./configure`

```
Do you wish to build TensorFlow with Google Cloud Platform support? [y/N] N
```

Do?
